DOC.brief_summary: This study will enroll people with SCI who are receiving physical therapy/exercise training. The goal is to understand if standing on a platform and receiving WBV prior to training results in decreased spasticity and improved walking ability compared to training alone.
DOC.brief_title: Dose-Response Effects of Whole Body Vibration on Spasticity and Walking in SCI
DOC.detailed_description: Phase 1 of this study has been successfully completed. The results of Phase 1 indicate that the combination of high-frequency (50Hz) and long duration 6 minutes (delivered in eight 45-sec bouts) of WBV was associated with the largest change in spasticity (as measured by the pendulum test). It also seems feasible that WBV would serve as a priming stimulus to increase responsiveness to training. The goal for Phase 2 is to understand if adding WBV to physical therapy/exercise training results in decreased spasticity and improved walking ability compared to the training alone. Two different doses of WBV, a short dose and a long dose will be tested.
DOC.criteria: Be currently participating in Shepherd STEP program or Beyond Therapy have spinal cord injury of at least 6 months duration. be between the ages of 16 65 years old. be able to stand for at least one minute using the upper extremities for balance only. be able to move one leg at least a small amount using whatever devices are most helpful for you. have at least mild spasticity affecting the lower extremity muscles. be able to transfer from sit to stand requiring no more than moderate assistance of one person. be able to understand and provide own consent You may participate if you use prescription medications, including baclofen pump for control of spasticity, as the dosage is stable. progressive or potentially progressive spinal lesions, including degenerative, or progressive vascular disorders of the spine and/or spinal cord. neurologic level below spinal level T12 history of cardiovascular irregularities problems following instructions orthopedic problems that would limit your participation in the protocol (e.g. knee or hip flexion contractures of greater than 10 degrees).
